COVID-19 UNDP 2016-2021: Institutional Strengthening for the Forest Sector Development

description.narrative: Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 UNDP has applied to Sida for funding of 43 MSEK and Additional funding of 13MSEK for the period of four years of the project implementation. The intervention aims at Institutional strengthening for forest sector development at national-, regional- and district level. Thus, the project will contribute to the Swedish development cooperation strategy (2016-2020) in building the capacity of the sector to deliver a better environment through sustainable natural resources management and ecosystem management in way that improve the livelihood of rural community through private sector engagement. The government and local community has fully engaged on the planning and implementation process of the project. Hence, this will establish a sense of ownership at community level.

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Interventionen syftar till att stärka den institutionella kapaciteten hos det nybildade ministeriet för miljö, skog och klimatförändringar på nationell-, regional- och lokal( Woreda- nivå genom att 1) stärka den institutionella kapaciteten hos skogsbruket på alla nivåer (federal, regional och Woreda); 2) Förbättra skogsskydd och utvecklingav hållbart jordbruk; 3) Underlätta privata sektorns medverkan i skogsutveckling 4) främja vetenskap och innovation för att öka hållbart skogsbruk; och; 5) Förbättra intressenter engagemang i skogsutveckling. UNDP har ett särskilt programkontor som stöder Miljöministeriet med ansvar för miljö, skog och klimatförändringar (MEFCC) i genomförandet av insatsen.
Insatsen vänder sig till lokala myndigheter och privata aktörer, samt aktörer i civilsamhället på lokal nivå. Institutionsutveckling på nationell, regional och lokal nivå med stöd från en eller flera svenska institutioner kommer att planeras för och startas upp under första året av svenskt stöd. Plattformar för samverkan på de olika nivåerna mellan staten och det civila samhället och den privata sektorn kommer också att sättas upp. Programmet innehåller också stöd till projekt på lokal nivå för t.ex. småskalig skogsvård och småskaligt miljövänligt jordbruk som inte minskar areal för skog. UNDP har ansvar för planering och uppföljning av programmet och Norge är samfinansiär sedan 2015. 8 % av budgeten går till UNDPs administrativa kostnader och 92 % är för programverksamhet inklusive kapacitetsutveckling och aktiviterer på nationell, regional och lokal nivå. Av dessa medel går 30% till aktiviteter på nationell nivå och 70% till lokal nivå för särskild kapacitetsutveckling på lokal nivå och för projekt på lokal nivå. UNDP har ansvar för planering och uppföljning av programmet och hela budgeten. För att kunna rapportera till oss kommer de att få rapportering och revisioner från miljöministeriet som vidareförmedlar medel till federal och lokal nivå och får finansiell och resultatrapportering på arbetsplaner från dessa institutioner. Svenska institutioner kommer ha avtal direkt med UNDP och kapacitetsutveckling och upphandlade varor och konsulter av UNDP betalas direkt från UNDP medan en del andra aktiviteter på nationell nivå och på lokal nivå kommer att betalas från ett särskilt konto på miljöministeriet, och delegerade medel till regional och lokal nivå, dit medel överförs efter tillfredsställande resultat- och finansiell rapportering. En stor andel av projekt kommer att distributeras till genomförande på lokal nivå. UNDP och Sida bedömer att Miljöministeriet har kapacitet att följa upp planer och medel på regional- och distriktsnivå. Programkontoret på UNDP och på miljöministeriet assisterar och bygger kapacitet. Resultat som har åstadkommits i programmet sedan 2015 är pilotprogram i 9 distrikt, en avslutad studie av genomförarbarhet, anställning av personal i pilotdistrikten, planering för aktionsplaner i 3 regioner, ett klart utkast för en tio-årig skogsplan, utbildning av ministeriets och distriktens personal och projektanställda i utveckling av skog och hantering av skog samt konsultationer med intressenter och aktiviterer för medvetandegörande om skogens möjligheter och utmaningar.

The overall objective the programme is to support government effort in promoting sustainable forest management through enhanced forest business. The program will invlove private sectors in the whole value chains. Thus, the theory of change has been updated based on the new forest business concept desinged by government. By the 2020, the governance systems, use of technologies and practices, and financing mechanisms that promote low carbon climate-resilient economy and society are expected to be improve at all levels(Federal, Regional and Woreda). At the end of the development intervention the attitude, behaviour and living conditions of the local community will positively impacted. In addition to the previous objective of the program from 2016-2020, the overall objective of the proposed expanded program (2018-2021) is to promote sustainable and competitive tree-based production systems in the rural and urban landscapes of Ethiopia thereby contributing to community and ecosystems resilience. The program objective is well aligned to the ten year National Forest Sector Development Program (NFSDP) of Ethiopia. and the expanded support in the following ways;• To formulate directives and regulations for operationalizing of the forest sector policy and proclamation;• To strengthen institutional capacity of the forest sector at systemic, organizational and individual level, include the capacity of extention workers and through them forest growing farmers. • To establish robust and effective information flow among the forest sector institutions• To initiate public and private sector partnership;• To support technology generation and development in the forest sector.• To enhance sustainable forest production• To describe diversity and dynamics over time of various new production systems• To enhance payment for ecosystem service scheme• To promote forest landscape restoration in degraded natural forests and communal lands• To create model city parks to foster environmental stewardship in selected cities

description.narrative: The report covers the period from January 1, 2018- December 30,2018. The project delivered on the following major results as here under; Output 1: The institutional capacity of the forest sector strengthened 1. Strengthened forest management offices at various levels with improved the efficiency and effectiveness of the forest sector initiatives. Furthermore, these offices have become good showcases for the government on the potential of strong forest sector institution at different levels. 2. A successful analysis of the current situation of the forest sector focusing on the intended effects beyond the existing challenges. Strengthened forest sector institutional capacity with clear national roadmap, implying clearer vision and targets for the coming ten years. Forest sector is in a better position to pursue different strategies and approaches for the implementation of the national plan. Output II. Forest Development Enhanced for their multiple benefits 1. Community ownership improved on A/R and ANR sites supported by local bylaws. Forest land use right of the community is legally secured through certification systems with direct implication for sustainability. The effectiveness of local by-laws and forest user groups revealed the need for robust forestry institutional arrangement at local level. 2. Further degradation of land and vegetation due to deforestation and soil erosion reduced. Landslides, downstream run-off and flooding of lower watersheds minimized due to the physical and biological soil and water conservation measures, free grazing reduced and biodiversity of degraded areas improved. Productivity of degraded lands improved through animal forage and bee forage production. Additional income generated from selling grass and honey. Re-growth of indigenous flora and reintroduction of wildlife species witnessed in the rehabilitated areas. 3. Further degradation of forest lands due to deforestation and soil erosion reduced. Flooding of lower watersheds minimized due to the physical and biological soil and water conservation measures. Average survival rate of seedling improved to 80.7%. Community cohesion improved through establishment of forest users’ association. Re-growth of indigenous flora and reintroduction of wildlife species witnessed in the new forest lands, contributing for biodiversity conservation. Additional income generated by selling grass from the new short rotation forest areas through cut-and-carry system. Income of the communities increased from casual labour. Community ownership improved on A/R sites supported by local bylaws and ownership certification systems with direct implication for sustainability. Communities are expecting better economic return from the plantations established on their previously unproductive private crop land and/or communal land, indicating better economic opportunity. Key innovations include constructing soil and water conservation structures before planting trees, and much post-planting care including watering during peak dry spells. 4. The proposed alternative livelihood systems have been provided alternative means of income for local communities by supplementing the existing income of households, women and youth groups. The three forest user groups organize under community forestry scheme earned 20,000birr each. These groups started to get early benefit from selling grass from the plantation sites. The Youth group of eight members organized for tree seedling production have earned 40,000 ETH birr from selling seedlings. Beneficiaries who received chicken earned an average of 400-600 ETB birr per month per household. The beneficiaries have also supplemented their family nutrition from the egg. Many of the daily laborers working in the project were able to send their children to school and some of them are able to support their families through forming traditional village level saving system ‘‘EQUB’’, which improves household resilience. Women and land less or unemployed Youth are benefiting from the different livelihood components such as fattening, fruit production & beekeeping. Output III: Promote science and innovation in the sector 1. few research projects on key government priorities and thematic forestry topics are ready to be supported by the Swedish financial support2. Academic exchange and joint research and education program initiated with Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences (SLU)3. MoU signed with SLU, Wondo Genet and Mertolemariam Colleges to initiate the implementation of the next generation program
